title: In h1 nmr spectroscopy, what is doublets of doublets? - Quora

response.answer_text: You will encounter a doublet of doublet when a group of magnetically identical protons ( e.g. CH3 or CH2) is coupled with 2 different protons, with different coupling constants ( this is usually called an AMX system). The signal for that group will then be made of 4 peaks of identical area.  The reason is that the signal will be doubled a first time for the first coupling, resulting in a doublet ( 2 peaks of identical area). That signal is then doubled again for the 2nd coupling, causing each peak to be doubled, once again with identical area. So you end up with 4 peaks with identical area. You will be able to determine the 2nd coupling constant using the difference in chemical shift between peaks 1 and 2, or peaks 3 and 4. This will be the smallest of the 2. You can then determine the other coupling constant using peaks 1 and 3 or peaks 2 and 4.  Note that if the coupling constant have the same value, the two middle peaks will be combined in a single peak with an area twice as large as outside peaks, making the signal look like a triplet, whether your group is coupled with 2 identical protons (in which case you have a regular triplet) or with 2 different protons who happen to be coupled with the same coupling constant: this is called an apparent doublet. Here is an example where you should see a doublet of doublet: 3-chloro-1-nitro-prop-1-ene (NO2-CH=CH-CH2Cl). That CH2 will be coupled with both vinylic protons, the first in J3, the second in J4. The 2 constants should be different, probably around 7Hz for the J3 and between 1 and 3Hz (depending on the stereochemistry of the double bond) for the J4.

Simply stating, a doublet of doublets is a nested system of doublets that comes from the fact that the systems of spins that generate the signals have different coupling constants coupling constants.   taken from Illustrated Glossary of Organic Chemistry
